meta_data.title: The Further Into the Bible We Get the More This Clothing Metaphor Is Coming Into Focus
meta_data.subtitle: Galatians 3:26-29 Thanks to everyone who supports TMBH at  You're the reason we can all do this together!  Music by

transcription_data.text: Thestis virum facet, am I saying that right? It's the Latin expression for the clothes maketh the man. You and I have been processing this expression as it relates to the Bible for the last basically week now. And I tell you, I've got no regrets because what we're discovering is this amazing bit of material at the end of Galatians chapter three, right in the middle of it, there's a metaphor. It says that for all of you who were baptized into Christ, have clothed yourselves with Christ. We've taken a week to go and track down that motif, that metaphor through all of the Bible up through the teachings of Christ. That's where we left off last time around. And I for one am finding this already awesomely wonderful passage at the end of Galatians three to be even awesomer and wonder floor than I thought it was before having done this clothes maketh the man motif jaunt through the Bible. Well, guess what? We got one more day of that. And what we have seen, if you've been with me through the last week, is that where your eye doctor flips through the different lenses and she's like, here, look at this one. Is that better? No, is this better? A little, is this better? A little, a little, a little until finally it's so in focus that you like forgotten how clear something could be. And you're like, dang, doctor, that's perfect. Thank you, ma'am. Well, through the Bible, the clothes make it the man motif, the being robed in something and having that inform the essence of the person who is robed in it, that motif goes from there but vague to clearer, clearer, clearer, clearer, clearer, clearer to the end of the Old Testament, really clear to Jesus hitting the nail on the head in Luke 15 with the parable of the prodigal son, which is a reference back to Zechariah 3 to even more explicitly spelled out as we work our way through the rest of the New Testament. And that is what we're going to do today in what maybe no particular order. We'll just go in the through the Bible order of it. Romans 13, 14, the clothes make it the man. Check this out. Let us behave decently as in the daytime, not in orgies and drunkenness, not in sexual immorality and debauchery, not in dissension and jealousy. I think I just wanted to say all those words. I probably didn't need to read verse 13, but it happened and now verse 14 is going to make more sense. Rather, clothe yourselves with the Lord Jesus Christ and do not think about how to gratify the desires of the sinful nature. There's that sare concept again. You put on this clothing, you put on Christ, you live life by the spirit. That's giving a nod to stuff we're going to get into as we work further ahead in Galatians. Let's keep going. Next book, 1 Corinthians 15, couple pages away. I got it right here. This is a big chapter. I'm going to read you a couple verses here starting in verse 51. Listen, I tell you a mystery will not all sleep, but will all be changed. There's that essence language again. In a flash in the twinkling of an eye at the last trumpet for the trumpet will sound and the dead will be raised imperishable and we will be changed essence language, transformation language. It's all there. For the perishable must clothe itself with the imperishable and the mortal with immortality. When the perishable has been clothed with the imperishable and the mortal with immortality, then the saying that is written will come true. Death has been swallowed up in victory. Where Odeth is your victory. Where Odeth is your sting. The sting of death is sin and the power of sin is the law. But thanks be to God, he gives us the victory through our Lord Jesus Christ. Dang, that's really good Bible. I mean, that should probably get its whole day. That was really good Bible. But at this point, we've been at it for a week. You're picking up what I'm putting down and you're seeing with same eyes or ears that I'm encountering with. You're seeing how this is taking on a tighter focus the further we get into the Bible. It's going from a motif that's a little open ended to a motif that is getting paid off with crystal clarity. Here's one and you know this one and honestly, if you're going to memorize five verses from the Bible, probably get this one. 2 Corinthians 5, 21, God made him who had no sin to be sin for us so that in him we might become the righteousness of God. I know that doesn't have explicit clothes make it the man language there, but it's just next in order. So I thought I'd hit it on the way by the point being it's Sarah, it's essence, it's transformation. Christ became sin, robed in it in the biblical sense like it's him. He owns it. It's our sin. It's his sin. He became sin so that in him we might become the righteousness of God, not a star the righteousness of God for a minute. I'm happy now, but maybe I'll be sad later. Sarah the righteousness of God, become it, put it on, wear it. The clothes make it the man and I have been made the righteousness of God. Let's keep going. Well, I suppose the next thing is we're turning pages right through the Bible is where we've been. Chapter three, so let's just do it in order. You're all sons of God through faith in Christ Jesus. For all of you who were baptized into Christ have clothed yourselves with Christ. There's either Juneau Greek, slave nor free, male nor female, for you are all one in Christ Jesus. If you belong to Christ, then you are Abraham's seed and heirs according to the promise. Sarah, robed, clothed. This is imparted by God. Just as the high priest and Zechariah is changed out of those filthy garments that are kind of a metaphor for everything that had gone wrong for the Jewish people, God's chosen people before covered in all the ick of all of that. Just as those garments were swapped out for something clean and made right at the expense of God provided by God. So that's what we're seeing here. We are made sons of God, heirs of God. We have clothed ourselves with Christ, a righteousness of robing provided by God himself. All right. I keep going. Next up is Galatians and Galatians 4. Let's start in verse 22. You were taught with regard to your former way of life to put off your old self, which is being corrupted by its deceitful desires to be made new in attitude of your minds and to put on the new self created to be like God in true righteousness and holiness. There's that language again, it goes on to more language like put off falsehood. And the whole idea here is again, just like back in Zechariah or just like the prodigal son returning, get those filthy robes off. That is my son, my daughter, my heir, my child. As a participant in my kingdom, that is an attendee of my banquet who is invited. Get them in the proper attire that indicates that my riches and my righteousness, my standing is upon them and that they are identified with my household. So the idea here in Ephesians chapter 4 is we're taking off the stuff that identifies us with a lesser corrupted household and we're being given the robes, the stuff to put on from God that identifies with his household of Ephesians 6, 11. You knew this one was coming probably. I'll start in verse 10. Finally, be strong in the Lord and it is mighty power. Put on the full armor of God so that you can take your stand against the devil's schemes for our struggle is not against flesh and blood, but against the rulers, against the authorities, against the powers of this dark world and against the spiritual forces of evil in the heavenly realms. Therefore, put on the full armor of God. All of this again is in keeping with the idea of the clothes make of the man and who provides the clothing. God, what is it representative of? His righteousness, his power to use a fancy word. It's sanctification that is sanctified, sanctus, holy, to be set apart for God, to be made right, to live life by the Spirit, which is a life that one cannot live by their own strength, by their own power or by the law. Yes, I'm stalling a little bit while also doing theology, Colossians 3, 12. Therefore, as God's chosen people, holy and dearly loved, clothe yourselves with compassion, kindness, humility, gentleness, and patience. Bear with each other and forgive whatever grievances you might have against one another. Forgive, as the Lord forgave you. And over all these virtues, put on love, which binds them all together in perfect unity. I wanted to get in all the rest of the New Testament, the clothes make up the man stuff in one day, but I don't want to shortchange us actually reading the text and you actually encountering it for yourself. So what do you know? We're just going to take another day and we're going to do a whole lot more deep dive Bible tomorrow. And then, then, finally then, we will be on de Galatians chapter 4. We'll pick up where we left off next time around. I'm Matt. This is the 10 Minute Bible Hour Podcast. Let's do this again soon.
